The economy looks pretty good. The gas price is not high. What is wrong with the country?

post_info.post_title: Is the country on the right track?

Matthew S

The economy looks pretty good. The gas price is not high. What is wrong with the country?

 
 That republicans exist and that they are in power. That gay people are oppressed and discriminated against. That there are people homeless. That there are people that go hungry. That there are people who have lost their jobs to the greed of business. That there is religious extremism run rampant.
matroid

That republicans exist and that they are in power. That gay people are oppressed and discriminated against. That there are people homeless. That there are people that go hungry. That there are people who have lost their jobs to the greed of business. That there is religious extremism run rampant.

 
 I think the homeless problem and the hunger problem are always there
 no matter what party is in power. Even when Clinton was in office,
 those social problems were no better. Homeless people are always
 homeless regardless of economic situation. The only solution to that
 problem is education. If we can make sure that there are no high
 school dropouts, then the number of homeless people would be reduced
 sharply. The same thing for the hungry people. Education, education,
 education.
 
 As for the gay discrimination problem, it is too complicated. The science
 cannot answer the reason for the gay phenomenon. For the problem of jobless
 people, although it is a sad one, the unemployment rate is at 4.7% currently,
 that is not high at all. Right now, the high tech industry is
 booming. There is a great shortage for high tech people. The
 solution for the unemployment problem is still education. If you
 have the guts, you have a job. That is fair to everybody.
 
 I think the greed problem of business is exaggerated by some
 politicians. Most of the companies are not too bad, only a small
 portion of them are greedy like Enron. Don't blame the capitalism
 like a socialist. The idea of socialism is the worst.
 
 Republicans and Democrats have different views on those social
 problems. They should respect each other.

post_info.post_title: You point out some very important problems.

johnhanks

The economy looks pretty good. The gas price is not high. What is wrong with the country?

 
 The scenes of chaos, poverty and deprivation beamed around the world in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina - and again on its anniversary - suggest that quite a lot might be. The fact that the USA ranks 36th in the world's infant mortality tables - below Macau, Slovenia or Cuba, and with a rate nearly three times the lowest (Singapore) - might also be food for thought.
Jo Bennett
Why not blame capitalism? It's the source of most of the problems of western society.
georged

The economy looks pretty good. The gas price is not high. What is wrong with the country?

 
 I don't consider any country driving its economy with unsustainable, abnormal public and personal debt to be good, especially the largest economy in the world. Combine that with the highest per-capita rate of incarceration in the developed world, an inbred failed manufacturing industry, migration to a two-tiered society of haves and have nots, fiscal inability to improve crumbling and outdated infrastructure for some of what's wrong with the US. We've become fat, lazy and refuse to accept the fact we're a declining empire. To maintain the facade, we accelerate the drain on our national wealth with armed aggression to maintain Petrodollar domination that supplies our massive debt requirements while our have-not population increases and growth of racism and mythical belief system legislation disguised as democratic patriotism removes civil rights. 
 
 As to gas prices not being high, clogged commercial vehicle auctions are returning inefficient used SUVs and pickups back to dealerships with bulging inventories of new, inefficient SUVs and pickups. Any media source describes the desperate financial condition of the US vehicle manufacturing sector. That's the result of decades of poor management and a public coping with stagnated wages, understated inflation and migration to an internal transaction service economy plagued by debt from loss of value added exports.
 
 Not a pretty picture, but until the US public takes government back from entrenched, self-serving politicians it'll become far worse. Unfortunately, judging from the apathetic blind patriot posts swallowing government propaganda on this and other forums, it's going to be a hard fall before that change transpires.
Steeeeve

The economy looks pretty good. The gas price is not high. What is wrong with the country?

 
 They got ya! 
 Remember 2 years ago when you were driving down the road and saying "2 bucks a gallon? Screw that!"
 Now you are ok with $2.35.....what a genius way of selling goods! Change the perspective.
 Gas is still high and don't let a little drop fool you.
 As for the right track...there is no right track :)
 
 As for everyone's response...it is almost as if you put your posts on auto-respond. At this point I could right all of your posts for you guys and save lots of time :)
daewoo

They got ya! 
 Remember 2 years ago when you were driving down the road and saying "2 bucks a gallon? Screw that!"
 Now you are ok with $2.35.....what a genius way of selling goods! Change the perspective.
 Gas is still high and don't let a little drop fool you.
 As for the right track...there is no right track :)
 

 
 LOL. No kidding! The other day I was listening to some idiot drone on about how cheap oil has gotten. Oil is over SIXTY DOLLARS per barrel. That is NOT cheap. The fact that it is not $78 does NOT make $64 cheap.
daewoo

Why not blame capitalism? It's the source of most of the problems of western society.

 
 Because it is not so much the capitalist theory that is the problem as it is our implementation of it.

LOL. No kidding! The other day I was listening to some idiot drone on about how cheap oil has gotten. Oil is over SIXTY DOLLARS per barrel. That is NOT cheap. The fact that it is not $78 does NOT make $64 cheap.

 
 If I were Coke I would jack up the price of a bottle of coke to $4 and then after a year or two drop it down to $3 and then have everyone be happy they are paying for a cheap bottle of coke.

 they can blame it on increased chinese demand, thus making it a patriotic duty to continue buying coke just to screw those dirty, baby eating socialists.

Because it is not so much the capitalist theory that is the problem as it is our implementation of it.

 
 which is precisely the same argument made by marxists about communism.
JohnM

On the wrong track, yes, but not for the reasons given.
 
 On the wrong track at least since the degredation of citizenship through coerced registration from birth through misuse of the social security system, since being required to have government approval to be employed, since the intrusive hoopla of manditory one-way safety through politically driven seatbelt and car seat laws. On the wrong track since we acquiesced to government going beyond reasonable and constitutional limits and thinking it must sold all problems and dilemmas.

 I think that is true of so many things. Wanna screw something up royal? -- add humans.

I think that is true of so many things. Wanna screw something up royal? -- add humans.
 
 I heard once that a gallon (or maybe is was a barrel) of Coca Cola (syrup) is more expensive than the same amount of oil. Things that make you go hmmm.

 
 Actually I think if we had a more capitalistic society, we'd be a lot better off. The corporate welfare culture that Congress has supported for decades stifles compeition, and retarded advancement. Large corporations seek to eliminate compeition within their fields as soon as they can. The Us is in many ways, a non-capitalistic country. The freer the market, the freer the people.
